Furfural (FFA) is regarded as one of the most important platform chemicals derived directly from biomass and its downstream hydrogenation product of furfural alcohol (FOL) has important industrial value. Therefore, the development of efficient non-noble metals catalysts for FFA hydrogenation to FOL is highly desirable. Herein, a series of Cu-Ni alloy supported on MCM-41 catalysts are developed for catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of FFA into FOL using 2-propanol as hydrogen source and solvent. The Cu-Ni alloy particles are verified by HRTEM and XRD analysis and the introduction of Ni metal improves the dispersion of Cu. Simultaneously, the effects of the Cu-Ni metals content and the Cu/Ni ratio of catalysts in CTH of FFA to FOL are studied. The 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 shows the best catalytic performance with 94.5% of FFA conversion and ∼x223C 99% of FOL selectivity, which depends on the synergistic effect within the Cu and Ni metals and moderate hydrogenation capacity of 2-propanol. More importantly, the catalyst still sustains good performance of FFA hydrogenation after being used five times. The possible reaction pathway for CTH of FFA over Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalyst is discussed: active hydrogens from 2-propanol attack the carbonyl group of FFA activated by metal sites to form FOL. This work provides a feasible sight to develop a referable catalyst system for the industrial CTH of FFA. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cu-Ni alloy catalysts Furfural Furfural alcohol Catalytic transfer hydrogenation 1 Introduction Given the exhaustion of fossil resource reserves as well the deterioration of global ecology, the emerging non-fossil energy sources such as solar energy and renewable biomass, have entered the public spotlight [1]. In the road map for the exploitation of biomass sustainable sources, catalytic upgrading of biomass derivative platform compounds plays a vital role in producing high value-added chemicals and liquid fuels [2]. In this regard, furfural (FFA), as a high value-added compound derived from biomass, has been highlighted recently. It not only can be produced from agricultural resources, such as corn cob and sugarcane bagasse, but also is readily available from semi-cellulose waste by acidic hydrolysis [3–5] (Scheme 1). The most important and widespread process of FFA is hydrogenation. Various valuable compounds can be produced by hydrogenation, such as furfural alcohol (FOL) [6], tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) [7], and 2-methylfuran (2-MF) [8,9], etc. Among them, the most acceptable product is FOL, a key intermediate for the manufacture of essential industrial compounds and many fine chemicals, such as synthetic fibers, lubricants, adhesives, and various solvents [10]. About 62% of FFA is used to produce FOL through hydrogenation [7]. Over the past decades, the industrial production of FOL mainly depended on direct hydrogenation of FFA at high pressure H2 using copper chromite (Cu-Cr) catalyst, which could provide a moderate activity in FFA conversion and relatively high selectivity toward FOL. But it is a hazardous process due to harsh reaction conditions (180 °C, 5–10 MPa H2). Over time, the catalyst was degraded and Cr6+ was formed, causing a large hazard to the environment. Therefore, the design of alternative chromium-free catalysts is highly desirable. Typically, various metallic catalysts, including Cu [11], Ni [12], Pd [13], and Pt [14] have been applied for FFA hydrogenation to FOL under pressurized pure H2 with high FFA conversion and good product selectivity. Nevertheless, the usage of molecular hydrogen depends on fossil resources and is potentially dangerous, for example, leakage of gas and explosion of reactors, etc. Hence, to avoid these drawbacks, catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) becomes a considerable alternative, which replaces molecular hydrogen with liquid hydrogen donors. CTH normally includes the dehydrogenation of H donor and synchronous hydrogenation of FFA. Although both lower alcohols (ethanol [15], 2-propanol [16], 2-butanol [17]) and formic acid [18] show excellent dehydrogenation activity, the former is preferable due to the easy production from biomass. Particularly, 2-propanol is preferentially considered as a sustainable hydrogen donor with higher activity in FFA hydrogenation. Meanwhile, multiple noble and non-noble metals catalysts have been employed for CTH of FFA to FOL. For instance, Wang et al. used 6% Ru/mZrH as catalysts. 97% FFA conversion with 96% FOL yield was obtained at 150 °C using ethanol as the hydrogen donor [15]. While the high cost of Ru metal limits the application in industrial production. Therefore, the development of low-cost and efficient non-noble metallic catalysts for CTH of FFA into FOL is urgent. Generally, the copper-based catalysts usually show high selectivity but low activity. Therefore, several strategies have been proposed to improve the conversion by adding second metals [18–20], additives [21], metal oxide [22–24] and so on. Villaverde et al. prepared a series of Cu-Mg-Al catalysts via coprecipitation method at the constant PH and tested catalytic performance in FFA hydrogenation. The obtained results proved that FFA could convert to FOL completely with Cu(40%)-Mg-Al at optimal operating conditions (150 °C, 6 h) [25]. Weerachawanasak et al. developed a series of CuNi/SiO2 catalysts with various metals loading from 2 wt% to 5 wt% for hydrogenation of FFA to FOL, the bimetallic 2% Ni-5% Cu/SiO2 catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity with 94% of FFA conversion and FOL selectivity of 64%. Obviously, the selectivity of FOL is not excellent [26]. Therefore, to further improve the catalytic performance of Cu-Ni alloy catalysts in FFA hydrogenation to FOL, a series of bimetallic Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalysts with different metals content and Cu/Ni ratios were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method and employed in the moderate CTH of FFA to FOL using 2-propanol as hydrogen donor and solvent. Herein, the effects of Cu-Ni metals content, Cu/Ni ratios in catalyst, catalyst amount, reaction time, temperature, FFA concentration during the reaction were investigated, and the reusability of 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 was studied as well. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Tetraethoxysilane (TEOS, 99%), Cetyltrimethylammonium Bromide (CTAB, 99%), NH4OH (25%−28%), Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2•6H2O, 99%), Copper (Ⅱ) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2•3H2O, 99%), Ethanol (99%), Deionized water (18.2 MΩ cm−1), Furfural (FFA, 99%), Furfural alcohol (FOL, 99%), 2-propanol (99%). All reagents and solvents were used directly without any further purification. 2.2 Catalysts preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of MCM-41 MCM-41 was prepared by the alkaline hydrothermal method according to Refs. [27,28]. Typically, 2.6 g CTAB was placed in the round-bottom flask and dissolved in 120 ml deionized water at 40 °C with stirring 30 min, then 9.5 g NH4OH (25−28%) was added into the solution. After 30 min, 10 g TEOS was added and stirred for 60 min. The mixture was pumped with 1 L deionized water. The obtained solid was dried for 12 h in a vacuum drying oven at 90 °C. Then calcination was performed for 5 h at 550 °C in a muffle furnace to remove CTAB. Finally, white powder was obtained. The successful synthesis of MCM-41 was confirmed by BET, XRD, FT-IR, and TEM. The synthesis scheme for MCM-41 materials is shown in Fig. S1. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalysts Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. The ethanol absorption capacity of the MCM-41 was tested to be 2.5 ml/g. The stoichiometric metal precursors Cu(NO3)2•3H2O and Ni(NO3)2•6H2O were dispersed in 2.5 mL ethanol by sonication for 30 min. Then the metal precursors solution was slowly impregnated onto 1 g of MCM-41 support under vigorous stirring to keep fully adsorption. The resulting mixture was dried for 4 h in a vacuum drying oven at 60 °C. Subsequently, obtained solid was ground and calcined in a muffle furnace at 120 °C for 4 h to remove moisture. Finally, the resulting samples were reduced in H2 flow (30 mL/min) with the ramp rate of 10 °C min−1 to 450 °C for 2 h [26]. Catalysts were named by the ratio of the metals quality to MCM-41 supports. It should note that “the metals quality” refers to all Cu and Ni species on MCM-41, including zero-valent metal and non-zero metal of oxide. For example, the 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 (or 15Cu-15Ni) catalyst means that the quality of all Cu species in the catalyst is 15 wt% of the MCM-41 quality, and the quality of all Ni species is also 15 wt% of the MCM-41 quality. The simplified synthesis scheme is shown in Scheme 2. 2.3 Catalytic performance tests The catalytic reaction of FFA hydrogenation was performed in a 20 mL of stainless steel autoclave with a magnetic stirrer. In a typical experiment, 90 mg of catalyst, 1.8 mmol of FFA (173 mg), and 10 mL of solvent were mixed in the autoclave, speed of stirring 800 rpm. Then the reactor was sealed and heated to a reaction temperature (the ramp rate is 10 °C⋅min−1). After the reaction, the stainless steel autoclave was cooled to the room temperature. Then the liquid product was filtered. The product was quantitatively analyzed by a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS, Agilent 8860 GC/5977B MS) with an HP-5MS capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm, Kromat Corporation, USA). For studying catalytic reusability performance, the obtained catalyst after filtering was reused after reduction at 450 °C for 2 h in H2 flow in the next reaction. The FFA conversion and the FOL selectivity can be calculated by the following formula. (1) Conversion = I n i t i a l m o l e s o f F F A − F i n a l m o l e s o f F F A I n i t i a l m o l e s o f F F A × 100 % (2) Selectivity = F i n a l m o l e s o f F O L I n i t i a l m o l e s o f F F A − F i n a l m o l e s o f F F A × 100 % 2.4 Characterization The N2 adsorption-desorption experiment was performed on a Micromeritics instrument (ASAP 2460) at −200 °C. The sample (about 100 mg) was placed in a clear glass adsorption tube. Then degassing was performed at 350 °C in N2 flow for 4 h to remove these absorbed impurities. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalysts were acquired on an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker AXS D8) fitting with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ= 0.1541 nm), the 2θ range from 5 to 90 ° at a scanning rate of 4 ° min−1. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis was performed using the Nicolet IS10 spectrometer of Thermo Company. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was measured in a Suprasystem X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (AXIS) instrument with an ALKα excitation source. The UV-1800 Spectrophotometer with 400–800 nm range was employed to collect spectra. The morphology of samples was characterized by a scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOJ JSM-7500F) instrument with 100 V to 30 kV acceleration voltage range and Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai, G2 F20) instrument. The TEM sample was prepared by dripping a drop of diluted suspension on a carbon-coated copper grid after dispersing in ethanol by sonicating for 10 min. To further observe the dispersion of metals on supports, the high angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy images (HAADF-STEM) and X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) also were acquired. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of pure MCM-41 and Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalysts with different metals content from 5 to 30 wt% are shown in Fig. 1 (a, b). MCM-41 sample displays a type IV isotherm with an H1 hysteresis loop (Fig. 1a), suggesting the successful synthesis of ordered mesoporous MCM-41 with a narrow pore diameter distribution (Fig. 1b) [29]. Besides, three Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalysts with different metals content show similar isotherms tendency with pure MCM-41, suggesting that the structure of MCM-41 was maintained integrally after loading metals. The specific surface areas and average pore sizes of pure MCM-41 and Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalysts are shown in Table 1 . Notably, the specific surface areas and pore volume decrease gradually with the increase of metals content. The reason is that metallic particles clogged the MCM-41 mesoporous pores. The pore size distribution also shows a similar tendency. However, the pore size of 30Cu-30Ni/MCM-41 catalyst becomes larger than pure MCM-41, which can be explained that excessive metals loading caused some new piled pores by accumulation metals particles. The low-angle XRD pattern of the prepared MCM-41 materials (Fig. S2) exhibits a strong peak at 2.1 ° assigned to 100 plane of MCM-41, which appears due to the hexagonal lattice of MCM-41. Besides, peaks at 2θ = 4.0 ° and 2θ = 4.6 ° can be deconvoluted into 110 and 200 planes, suggesting the formation of regular mesoporous pores of MCM-41 [30]. Fig. 1c exhibits the XRD patterns of MCM-41 and Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalysts with various metals content from 5 to 30 wt% under the Cu/Ni quality ratio of 1/1 on all catalysts. The broad diffraction peak at around 2θ = 22 ° can be detected on all samples due to MCM-41 (JCPDS Card No. 89–3433). In addition, these catalysts display the diffraction peaks gradually at 2θ = 43.5 °, 50.7 °, 74.6 ° with the increase of metals content. Compared with standard peaks position of Cu (2θ = 43.316 °, 50.448 °, 74.124 °, JCPDS Card No. 85–1326) and Ni (2θ = 44.496 °, 51.849 °, 76.381 °, JCPDS Card No. 87–0712), three peaks shift to intermediate angles between Cu and Ni, indicating the formation of Cu-Ni alloy particles. Fig. 1d shows the XRD patterns of catalysts with various metals quality ratios. The 30Cu/MCM-41 catalyst shows three strong diffraction peaks at 2θ=43.3 °, 50.4 °, and 74.1 °, corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of Cu (JCPDS Card No. 85–1326) respectively. However, three peaks shift to Ni standard peaks position and display shorten until almost disappearing with Ni content increasing to 30 wt%, indicating Ni metal benefits to the dispersion of metals particles on supports of MCM-41, which is consistent with previous literature [7,31]. The FT-IR spectra of the pure MCM-41 and Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 a. The absorption peaks at 1063 cm−1 and 800 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibrations of Si-O-Si and Si-O from MCM-41 separately [29]. Both absorption bands are retained completely after loading metals, which demonstrates the introduction of metals did not destroy the structure of MCM-41. Fig. 2b shows the general XPS spectra of 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 sample, where the characteristic peaks of Cu and Ni species are observed, indicating the successful introduction of both metals. To further investigate the chemical states of Cu and Ni species on the support surface, the high-resolution XPS spectra were collected. The Cu 2p spectrum (Fig. S3a) of 30Cu/MCM-41 catalyst can be divided into two species. The peaks at 935, 956 eV, and a weak satellite peak at ∼x223C 943 eV are assigned to Cu2+ species [32], showing the existence of CuO due to the inevitable oxidation by air. The strong peak at 932.8 eV is assigned to Cu0 or Cu1+, which is difficult to distinguish because of close binding energy of Cu0 and Cu1+. So auger Cu LMM spectrum was collected (Fig. S3b), peaks at 569.3 eV, 570.3 eV, 568.3 eV can be assigned to Cu2+, Cu1+, and Cu0, respectively, indicating possible co-presence of Cu2+, Cu+1, and Cu0 on the oxide layer [33]. Combined with the XRD result of 30Cu/MCM-41, three diffraction peaks were assigned to Cu completely without peaks of Cu2O and CuO, suggesting that the oxide layer is present in very small amounts and most Cu exists in the form of Cu0 in the bulk phase. Similarly, the Ni 2p XPS spectrum of 30Ni/MCM-41 catalyst (Fig. S3c) also appears in two different Ni species. The binding energy of 853 (2p1/2) and 870 eV (2p3/2) are assigned to Ni0. The other two peaks at 856 (2p1/2) and 873.3 eV (2p3/2) are corresponding to Ni2+ [34]. The appearance of Ni2+ confirmed the existence of the surface oxide layer. Furthermore, Fig. 2c, d shows the survey high-resolution spectra of the Cu and Ni elements on catalysts with different Cu/Ni ratios, respectively. We can observe the binding energy of Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 are shifted to higher with the increase in Cu content (Fig. 2c, from bottom to top), while the binding energy of Ni 2p1/2 and Ni 2p3/2 are shifted to lower with increasing Ni content (Fig. 2d, from top to bottom), inferring a probable electron transfer from Cu to Ni. These results agree well with the previous reports that alloying could influence the electronic structure of each component [26,35]. Generally, the XPS results reveal the alloy states of Cu and Ni, consisting of XRD results. The morphology of pure MCM-41 and the optimal catalyst of 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 was firstly investigated by scanning electronic microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As shown in Fig. 3 a, the low-magnification SEM image indicates that the MCM-41 consists of closely packed spherical particles ranging from 400 to 1000 nm with an average size of 550 nm and each particle surface are rough (Fig. S4a), in line with the results reported in the literature [36]. In more detail, the high-magnification TEM image of MCM-41 (Fig. 3b) displays clear pore canals with characteristic spacings of 4.248 nm, corresponding to highly ordered mesoporous MCM-41 [37], which can also be reflected on the different diffraction peaks of XRD (Fig. S2). The SEM image of 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 sample (Fig. 3c) displays that Cu-Ni alloy particles (white spots) adsorb on the rough outer surface of the MCM-41 supports uniformly. TEM image of 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst (Fig. 3d) shows that the particles are roughly 23.4 nm (inset) in diameters. Besides, no obvious Cu-Ni nanoparticles in the pores were observed and the original mesoporous structures of MCM-41 are maintained after loading metals (Fig. S4b). To further study the crystal structure of loading metals, the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image was performed (Fig. 3e), intuitively corroborating the formation of Cu-Ni alloy with the (111) interplanar distance of 0.206 nm between Cu (111, d = 0.203 nm) and Ni (111, d = 0.209 nm), as is also validated by the XRD results. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 3f) featuring coexistence of diffraction spots ((111), (200) planes) and diffraction rings suggests the polycrystalline large particles nature of Cu-Ni alloy. The X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis (Fig. 3h, i) confirms that Cu and Ni particles disperse on MCM-41 supports uniformly and the similar compositional distribution positions of Cu and Ni elements suggests the alloy structure. 3.2 Catalytic performance The results of FFA hydrogenation using 2-propanol as hydrogen donor and solvent on prepared catalysts with different metals content from 5 to 30 wt% and Cu/Ni ratios are presented in Fig. 4 . The conversion of FFA increases from 50.9 to 94.5% and the FOL selectivity from 55 to ∼x223C 99% with the increase of metals content from 5 to 15 wt% maintaining the same Cu/Ni quality ratio of 1/1 on all catalysts (Fig. 4a), largely ascribable to the more exposure of active sites. In most cases, increasing metals content of catalyst leads to higher conversion. While an adverse tendency is displayed with content further increasing to 30 wt% from 15 wt%, possibly due to dense metals particles agglomerate more easily in high temperature reduction process, resulting in a drastic reduction in surface area, which is unfavorable for catalytic performance. Besides, pure MCM-41 was also given catalytic activity test as a comparison. No transfer hydrogenation of FOL is observed at the same reaction conditions (Table S1, Entry 1), indicating that Cu and Ni metals are necessary for FFA hydrogenation to take place. Fig. 4b shows volcano-type curves of FFA conversion and FOL selectivity with different Cu/Ni ratios at total metals content maintaining 30 wt% on MCM-41. Of note, 30Cu/MCM-41 and 30Ni/MCM-41 catalysts show inferior hydrogenation activity. Nevertheless, the excellent result of 94.5% FFA conversion and ∼x223C 99% FOL selectivity are obtained with Cu/Ni ratio increasing to 1. The catalytic activity becomes lower when Cu/Ni ratio increases to>1, which indicates that the synergistic effect of Cu and Ni is necessary and operates excellently only under a suitable range of the ratio of Cu and Ni. Of note, lewis acidic metal cations (Cu2+ and Ni2+) exist on the surface of Cu-Ni nanoparticles measured by XPS. To research whether metal cations participated in the catalytic process, the optimal 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst was calcined for 2 h at 450 °C in a muffle furnace instead of H2. So Cu-Ni nanoparticles were oxidized to CuO and NiO by air completely (CuONiO/MCM-41), which can be confirmed by XRD result (Fig. S5). Subsequently, a catalytic performance test was performed (160 °C, 4 h). The result is that 29.6% of FFA conversion and 63.8% of FOL selectivity were obtained (Table S1, Entry 2). Considering the situ reduction of metallic oxide by 2-propanol at 160 °C, the used CuONiO/MCM-41 catalyst was performed XRD measurement under N2 protection. The diffraction peak of non-valent metals didn't been detected (Fig. S5). Therefore, the slight activity is attributed to metal cations. However, the absence of CuO and NiO diffraction peaks of Cu-Ni alloy catalysts in XRD results (Fig 1c, d) suggests that the small amount of Cu2+ and Ni2+ is only present on the surface oxide layer. Hence, non-valent metals still perform the main catalytic activity. The effects of different reaction conditions (catalyst amount, time, temperature, and FFA concentration) on the catalytic performance of FFA hydrogenation to FOL over 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst are shown in Fig. 5 . The FFA conversion increases gradually from 23.5 to 94.5% and the FOL selectivity from 18.8 to ∼x223C 99% with the amount of catalyst increasing from 17.5 to 90 mg of FFA (Fig. 5a). As seen in Fig. 5b, as the time increases from 1 to 4 h, FFA is converted to FOL gradually from 10.2 to 94.5%. Of note, without deep hydrogenation product of FFA was detected besides a 2-(diisopropoxymethyl) furan (DPOF) produced by the aldol condensation reaction of FFA with two molecules 2-propanol (Fig. S6). The FOL selectivity increases with the increase of the FFA conversion, which can be explained that a faster apparent rate of FOL inhibited the production of DPOF. Another important reaction factor for influencing the hydrogenation ability is temperature. As shown in Fig. 5c, FFA conversion increases from 15.5 to 94.5% as temperature increases from 120 to 160 °C, indicating that a higher temperature (160 °C) is demanded to facilitate complete hydrogenation of the FFA. In contrast, the selectivity of FOL always keeps at a high level (>80%) with a slight increase when the temperature increases from 130 to 160 °C, suggesting that the temperature has a slight effect on the formation rate of DPOF by-product. Additionally, the effect of FFA concentration is also discussed in Fig. 5d. The conversion of FFA increases from 59.6% at 0.12 mmol/mL to 94.5% at 0.18 mmol/mL, but drops to 29.6% at 0.36 mmol/mL. We speculate that too low FFA concentration can't ensure sufficient contact between catalyst and reactant. While too high concentration affects the diffusion rate of FFA, resulting in lower catalytic activity. Hence, the obtained reaction results exhibit that the optimal reaction conditions for FFA hydrogenation to FOL are the catalyst amount of 90 mg, reaction time of 4 h, reaction temperature of 160 °C, FFA concentration of 0.18 mmol/mL. Table 2 shows the comparison of 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst (Entry 1) and several catalysts synthesized by other researchers in catalytic hydrogenation of FFA to FOL (Entry 2–9). Compared with Cu-based (Entry 2), Ni-based (Entry 3), and Cu-Ni based catalysts (Entry 4, 5) in CTH using 2-propanol as a hydrogen source, the 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst shows not only excellent FFA conversion but also FOL selectivity. The reasonable explanation of high FFA conversion (94.5%) is attributed to the high metallic content (15 wt% Cu-15 wt% Ni/MCM-41) and the large catalyst amount. The metals particles agglomerated in high temperature caused the larger particle size, which may be meaning the slight loss of activity but the appropriate weakening of hydrogenation capacity. Therefore, the high FOL selectivity was obtained. It can be observed that the FOL selectivity is not very high using molecular hydrogen as a hydrogen source (Entry 6–9). The possible reason is that homolysis of molecular hydrogen produces two uncharged hydrogens generally. Compared with positively charged active producing by 2-propanol, the uncharged hydrogens attack not only the carbonyl group but also C=C bonds of FFA, causing the loss of FOL selectivity. It was known that industrial catalysis requires high selectivity and proper activity from a sustainability perspective. So our non-noble metal catalytic system with high selectivity is valuable and referable. 3.3 Reusability study Catalyst stability was investigated by its recycling performance. As seen in Fig. 6 , the 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst can be reused at least 5 times with little decline in FFA conversion, and the FOL selectivity shows almost no reduction, which suggests the catalyst has excellent recyclability. According to the XRD measurement result (Fig. S7a), the positions and amount of diffraction peaks from 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 remain unchanged after five reaction cycles, while three alloy peaks intensity becoming larger, which might be the result that the reduction atmosphere of 2-propanol at 160 °C led to the growth of Cu and Ni alloy crystal. The morphology of the used 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst was observed by SEM and TEM (Fig. S7b, c). The Cu-Ni alloy particles remain still to be absorbed on the outer surface of supports like the fresh catalyst (Fig. S7b). Furthermore, the pore structure of MCM-41 is not damaged (Fig. S7c). Combined with recycling performance, the increase in the size of alloy particles impacts catalytic hydrogenation properties slightly. 3.4 Possible reaction pathway To clarify hydrogen sources and catalytic active sites, a series of controlled experiments have been conducted. The catalytic reaction was performed without 2-propanol over 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst. The complete retention of FFA indicated that 2-propanol was the only hydrogen source (Table S1, Entry 3). In our previous discussion, no transfer hydrogenation of FOL was observed over pure MCM-41. Simultaneously, mono-Cu and mono-Ni catalysts showed low catalytic activity, indicating that Cu-Ni alloy is the necessary active site for FFA hydrogenation. Furthermore, it has been confirmed non-valent metals play the main role in catalytic activity rather than lewis acid (Cu2+ and Ni2+). So the CTH of FFA to FOL over 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst follow the catalytic mechanism of metal sites. The adsorption configuration plays a vital factor in metal sites catalytic of FFA hydrogenation. Tang et al. have confirmed that the adsorption configuration of FFA on the surface of Ni3Cu alloy catalyst trended to adopt a tilted orientation by theoretical adsorption energy simulation [43]. To verify whether our CuNi alloy catalysts also tend to tilt adsorption, the FT-IR of FFA adsorption was performed (Fig. 7 a). The 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 after absorbing FFA shows the C=O (1692 and 1673 cm−1) and C=C adsorption peaks (1463 and 1473 cm−1), indexing to the adsorption of the carbonyl group and the furan ring of FFA on the catalyst surface. However, the intensity ratio of C=O and C=C increases obviously compared with pure FFA, indicating the carbonyl group adsorbs on the catalyst surface more easily than the furan ring. Hence a typical tilted adsorption of FFA is confirmed. Besides, the 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst showed ∼x223C 99% of FOL selectivity in this work, indicating that the hydrogenation occurred only in the carbonyl group rather than furan ring of FFA, which can also confirm the tilted adsorption model: tilted orientation weakened the interaction of the furan ring with the metal active sites, causing that the activation of the furan ring was limited and facilitated the hydrogenation of FFA to FOL alone. Hence, combining experimental studies and relevant literatures [1,12,13,21,23,41,43,44], a possible reaction pathway for CTH of FFA to FOL catalyzed by 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst using 2-propanol as a hydrogen donor is proposed (Fig. 7b). First, 2-propanol molecule adsorbs on the metal active sites to form corresponding metal bound 2-propoxide. Meanwhile, the carbonyl group of FFA also adsorbs in the metal active sites by a tilted orientation. Subsequently, 2-propanol transfer to acetone via elimination reaction under the action of the active center, the two active hydrogens from -OH and α-C of 2-propanol absorb on the surface of metal active sites. Meanwhile, the carbonyl group of FFA is activated by metal sites and forms a transition state that is attacked by absorbed hydrogens easily. Next, active hydrogens react with the activated carbonyl group to form a FOL molecule. Finally, the generated FOL molecule desorbs from alloy catalysts. So far, the catalytic transfer hydrogenation completes all over and the next round of hydrogen transfer reaction will begin. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of bimetallic Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalysts are successfully prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method. The physical and chemical properties are studied by systemic characterization in detail. The XRD and TEM analysis results show that formed Cu-Ni alloy particles well disperse on the surface of MCM-41 supports and the addition of Ni species improves the dispersion of Cu. It is demonstrated that the bimetallic 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst exhibits the exceedingly high catalytic activity in CTH of FFA to FOL with 94.5% FFA conversion and ∼x223C 99% FOL selectivity at the optimal condition (160 °C, 4 h). The reaction pathway research suggests that the synergetic effect of Cu and Ni changes the adsorption configuration of FFA to a tilted orientation on the active sites, which weakens the interaction of the furan ring with the metal active sites. So the activation of the furan ring is limited and facilitates the hydrogenation of FFA to FOL alone. Besides, the 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 catalyst shows outstanding stability with no significant decrease after five runs. We believe that our efficient and stable Cu-Ni alloy catalysts can be applied in the hydrogenation of various carbonyl compounds. coredata.dc:description: Furfural (FFA) is regarded as one of the most important platform chemicals derived directly from biomass and its downstream hydrogenation product of furfural alcohol (FOL) has important industrial value. Therefore, the development of efficient non-noble metals catalysts for FFA hydrogenation to FOL is highly desirable. Herein, a series of Cu-Ni alloy supported on MCM-41 catalysts are developed for catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of FFA into FOL using 2-propanol as hydrogen source and solvent. The Cu-Ni alloy particles are verified by HRTEM and XRD analysis and the introduction of Ni metal improves the dispersion of Cu. Simultaneously, the effects of the Cu-Ni metals content and the Cu/Ni ratio of catalysts in CTH of FFA to FOL are studied. The 15Cu-15Ni/MCM-41 shows the best catalytic performance with 94.5% of FFA conversion and ∼x223C 99% of FOL selectivity, which depends on the synergistic effect within the Cu and Ni metals and moderate hydrogenation capacity of 2-propanol. More importantly, the catalyst still sustains good performance of FFA hydrogenation after being used five times. The possible reaction pathway for CTH of FFA over Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalyst is discussed: active hydrogens from 2-propanol attack the carbonyl group of FFA activated by metal sites to form FOL. This work provides a feasible sight to develop a referable catalyst system for the industrial CTH of FFA.
coredata.dc:title: Bimetallic Cu-Ni/MCM-41 catalyst for efficiently selective transfer hydrogenation of furfural into furfural alcohol
